intro: Tuberaria guttata var. inconspicua, commonly known as the inconspicuous bladderwort, is a small aquatic plant belonging to the family Lentibulariaceae. It is characterized by its tiny, bladder-like structures called bladders, which it uses to trap small aquatic organisms. The plant typically grows in freshwater habitats such as ponds and ditches, where it can anchor itself to submerged surfaces. Its leaves are usually simple and opposite, with a short stem that supports the bladders. This variety is less showy than its counterparts, hence its name, but it plays an important role in aquatic ecosystems by contributing to nutrient cycling.
